awd_abstract_narration:
Water Splitting Photocatalysis with Doped Metal Oxide Nanocrystals

In this Chemical Catalysis project, Frank Osterloh of the University of California at Davis is developing catalysts that can convert water into hydrogen and oxygen using sunlight. This technology creates a carbon-free pathway to hydrogen fuel using only sunlight as a renewable energy source.  The catalysts incorporate components for light absorption, electric charge separation, and water conversion. They are synthesized from inexpensive components and they are studied with a range of techniques. This work provides new insight into how sunlight interacts with small particles and how photochemical energy is converted into fuel.  The project has significant societal broader impact through contributions to clean energy technology. Dr. Osterloh also has created training opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students in inorganic chemistry and solar energy conversion.  He is active in outreach activities that present chemical demonstrations to the community and to underrepresented student groups, and develops online materials, which are made available to educate the public about the need for sustainable energy.

The Chemical Catalysis program supports Frank Osterloh at the University of California at Davis to develop microheterogeneous photocatalyst systems that can electrolyze water under sunlight illumination without any applied external bias. The catalysts incorporate components for light absorption, charge separation, water oxidation and water reduction. They are synthesized from abundant elements using a combination of scalable chemical reactions and chemical assembly and are characterized with microscopic, optical and electrical techniques. Their water splitting function is established through irradiation tests and electrochemistry, and their charge separation properties are quantified with surface photovoltage spectroscopy. This project provides new insights into photochemical charge generation and water photoelectrolysis with doped titania-based metal oxides. New quantitative relationships between the photocatalytic properties of the materials and their particle size and surface composition are also developed, with special consideration of the particle energetics and kinetics, and the electrolyte environment. Furthermore, the project has broader impacts by providing hands-on training to graduate and undergraduate students in the synthesis, handling, and understanding of nanoscale inorganic materials and their characterization with photophysical techniques and electrochemistry.  Professor Osterloh also develops new course content, laboratory experiments, chemical demonstrations, and online materials, with an emphasis of recruiting the next generation of STEM students, including underrepresented minorities, for renewable energy research.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of the project was to advance powdered photocatalysts that can convert water into hydrogen fuel under sunlight illumination without any applied external bias. Such catalysts are an alternative to solar cells, because they are less expensive because they are more easily produced on a large scale. As such they are a potential solution to climate change. 

Unfortunately, only very few water splitting catalysts are known today that can operate with sufficient efficiency for fuel production (> 10% based on solar energy input). Also, few known catalysts are stable under the water splitting conditions and few can function without the use of expensive and rare chemical elements. 

This project helped to overcome these problems with an experimental research program that focused on the chemical synthesis of modified metal oxide catalysts and on the understanding of their structure and properties. 

For example, this work provided a quantitative understanding of the effect of the dopants on the photocatalytic water splitting activity of aluminum doped strontium titanate. Using this catalyst we demonstrated unassisted hydrogen fuel production water and from sunlight with 0.11% efficiency. 

We showed that the water splitting function is retained in nanoparticles of the catalyst, although those smaller particles have much lower activity that the microparticles. This is attributed to charge recombination effects in the material and to shading from the co-catalyst. 

The formation of electric charge carriers in the photocatalysts is central to their function. To better understand these carrier dynamics, we conducted surface photovoltage spectroscopy studies on the metal oxides catalysts as a function of heat treatment and after adding metal impurities. We identified two kinds of defects that form after heating and that are likely involved in diminishing the activity of the catalysts. 

We also found that the addition of nickel, iron, copper, manganese, and rhodium metal to the catalysts improves their ability to generate a voltage under visible illumination, which is important for efficient solar energy conversion. However, these metals are often present in multiple oxidation states which reduces the photocatalytic activity of the materials through the formation of shunt defects.

The surface photovoltage spectroscopy tool was also applied to the testing of a core shell tandem photocatalyst for overall water splitting. Here, it was able to observe the photovoltage that develops across the catalyst. The photovoltage determines the electrical energy that is stored in the photocatalyst under illumination. 

We also completed a literature review of the potential and challenges of water splitting with inorganic photocatalysts. That literature review will promote the understanding of water splitting catalysis and current challenges in this field. 

In another published article, we performed a theoretical analysis on the difference between photocatalytic and photosynthetic materials. The former convert solar energy into fuels while the latter speed up chemical reactions that do not lead to deposition of photochemical energy in the products. This paper will help researchers develop better fuel-generating photocatalysts in the future. 

These and other publications on the topic of solar energy conversion can be downloaded from our research webpage at http://chemgroups.ucdavis.edu/~osterloh/index.htmland https://sites.google.com/site/osterlohlab/.

Most of the work in the project was conducted by over fourteen graduate and a dozen undergraduate students. These students were trained in the synthesis, handling, and understanding of inorganic materials and their study with photophysical techniques and electrochemistry. They also learned how to give presentations in public about their research. 

Under funding of this project, two students obtained their Ph.D. degrees and one a M.S. degree in chemistry and went on to accept jobs in the educational and industry sectors.  Several of the undergraduate students went on to join graduate programs to work on their doctorate degrees. 

The work also lead to new online materials that will educate next generation scientists on the preparation of inorganic photocatalysts and on their properties. For example, A video on the 'Synthesis of the Aluminum doped Strontium Titanate Overall Water Splitting Photocatalyst' was uploaded to youtube at https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=D0h1ZjU72Y8.

Lastly, over one dozen chemistry shows, open door days, and other outreach events were conducted with funding for this project. These events are designed to make children and young adults curious about science and to get them involved in it.
